linkTarget.anchoringText: Recent improvements in digital technology (big data implementations) data gathering and management techniques has fostered an important opportunity for the E&P industry. Through the appropriate implementation of knowledge-driven workflows, significant improvements in operational performance and cost efficiencies can be achieved by taking advantage of the big data revolution. Figure 1(a) presents a conceptual evolution of turning raw data in to actionable intelligence utilizing data analytical methods (Holdaway 2014).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1a, 1b
image-wrap.caption: (a) Analytics lifecycle turning raw data into knowledge and insight. (b) Potential oilfield analytics framework (Holdaway 2014, Kronkosky and Ettehadtavakkol 2016b).

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) Analytics lifecycle turning raw data into knowledge and insight. (b) Potential oilfield analytics framework (Holdaway 2014, Kronkosky and Ettehadtavakkol 2016b).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Analytics lifecycle turning raw data into knowledge and insight
Potential oilfield analytics framework (Holdaway 2014, Kronkosky and Ettehadtavakkol 2016b)

linkTarget.bib:
Holdaway, 2014
Keith Holdaway . 2014. Harness Oil and Gas Big Data with Analytics: Optimize Exploration and Production with Data Driven Models , John Wiley & Sons (Reprint).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The authors were provided a copy of a digitized version of the RRC Bulletin “82” database; a partial summary of the data fields available in both RRC Bulletin “82” and UIC databases is provided below in Table 1. Unfortunately, the RRC does not have a digital record of the information; what remains is voluminous comb-bound books at RRC district offices and occasionally at public libraries. A sample of the scanned data is shown in Figure 2.

Figure 3 is an example of a data visualization used to prepare estimates for primary and secondary reserves; these estimates are utilized to prepare S:P ratios. As highlight in the decline curve analysis, numerous predictor and response parameters and be quantified from this visualization. The following are brief descriptions of observations from Table 2:

image-wrap.label: Figure 3a, 3b
image-wrap.caption: (a.) Oil Rate vs. Time summary plot. (b) Oil Rate vs. Cummulative Oil Production.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a.) Oil Rate vs. Time summary plot. (b) Oil Rate vs. Cummulative Oil Production.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Oil Rate vs. Time summary plot
Oil Rate vs. Cummulative Oil Production

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 4 is a histogram of various predictor and response parameter (predictors were chosen at random for this toy example) for 522 secondary recovery projects. Secondary to Primary ratios (globally across the Permian Basin) have a median ratio of ~ 0.9; projects with S:P ratios greater than 2 should be evaluated to determine if these projects are outliers (or bad data) or potentially apart of a separate population (e.g. major fields/leases) - for this analysis we have chosen to keep these values in our analysis. Figures 5 and 6 are the summary outputs from our multivariate linear regression analysis (S:P = API Gravity + Injection Well /Production Well Ratio + Injection Pressure Gradient). We observe that while most of the predictor variables are significant (95% confindense level) as well as the overall model; residual standard error is quite high, which will lead to a large confindence band for the response.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Histograms of Predictor (green) and Response (red) parameters Secondary Recovery to Primary Ratio (S:P) - (Y) Prorosity - (X1) Permeability - (X2) API Gravity - (X3) Injection Well to Production Well Ratio - (X4) Injection Pressure Gradient - (X5)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Histograms of Predictor (green) and Response (red) parameters Secondary Recovery to Primary Ratio (S:P) - (Y) Prorosity - (X1) Permeability - (X2) API Gravity - (X3) Injection Well to Production Well Ratio - (X4) Injection Pressure Gradient - (X5)

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Injection Well to Production Well Ratio - (X4)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 4 is a histogram of various predictor and response parameter (predictors were chosen at random for this toy example) for 522 secondary recovery projects. Secondary to Primary ratios (globally across the Permian Basin) have a median ratio of ~ 0.9; projects with S:P ratios greater than 2 should be evaluated to determine if these projects are outliers (or bad data) or potentially apart of a separate population (e.g. major fields/leases) - for this analysis we have chosen to keep these values in our analysis. Figures 5 and 6 are the summary outputs from our multivariate linear regression analysis (S:P = API Gravity + Injection Well /Production Well Ratio + Injection Pressure Gradient). We observe that while most of the predictor variables are significant (95% confindense level) as well as the overall model; residual standard error is quite high, which will lead to a large confindence band for the response.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Multivariate Linear Model Summary Output from “R”

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 4 is a histogram of various predictor and response parameter (predictors were chosen at random for this toy example) for 522 secondary recovery projects. Secondary to Primary ratios (globally across the Permian Basin) have a median ratio of ~ 0.9; projects with S:P ratios greater than 2 should be evaluated to determine if these projects are outliers (or bad data) or potentially apart of a separate population (e.g. major fields/leases) - for this analysis we have chosen to keep these values in our analysis. Figures 5 and 6 are the summary outputs from our multivariate linear regression analysis (S:P = API Gravity + Injection Well /Production Well Ratio + Injection Pressure Gradient). We observe that while most of the predictor variables are significant (95% confindense level) as well as the overall model; residual standard error is quite high, which will lead to a large confindence band for the response.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Linear Model Diaignositc Plot Residuals vs Fitted Normal Q-Q Scale-Locations Residuals vs Leverage

formatted-caption.caption-text: Linear Model Diaignositc Plot Residuals vs Fitted Normal Q-Q Scale-Locations Residuals vs Leverage

linkTarget.anchoringText: The model outline above was a global model (San Andres reservoirs are located accross the entire Permian Basin); we anticipate spatial regression techniques will minimize the residual error, given Walters Law corollary - things tend to be near like things, providing models that are more robust. Figure 7 is provides a pictorial of how spatial distances can act as a weighting (e.g. closer projects have more weight) parameter to our regression model.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Example of Spatal Regression Concept - Northern project being evaluated utilizing spatial distance weights

formatted-caption.caption-text: Example of Spatal Regression Concept - Northern project being evaluated utilizing spatial distance weights
